DOCNAME: CASE OF VLADIMIR VASILYEV v. RUSSIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Degrading treatment;Inhuman treatment) (Substantive aspect);Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Civil proceedings;Article 6-1 - Fair hearing);Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Julia Laffranque;Khanlar Hajiyev;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and is serving a prison sentence in a correctional colony in the town of NORP , Perm Region ( GPE ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant was arrested on DATE in the town of GPE , GPE . On DATE ORG of GPE convicted him of , inter alia , attempted rape and several counts of murder , and sentenced him to death . On DATE ORG upheld the trial judgment in substance .

CARDINAL . In DATE the President of GPE issued an act of clemency in respect of the applicant , replacing the death penalty with life imprisonment . Thereafter , the applicant unsuccessfully sought a supervisory review of the conviction .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE the applicant was detained for various periods of time in GPE remand centre no . CARDINAL in GPE and other detention facilities . After his arrest the applicant was admitted to hospital because he had frostbite on his feet . He underwent a surgical operation resulting in the amputation of the fifth toe on his right foot and the distal part of his left foot . In DATE he was diagnosed with diabetes . In DATE the applicant was examined in a hospital . A group of experts concluded that he was able to work , except if it required physical exertion ; no disability status was attributed .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant was transferred to NORP colony no . QUANTITY in GPE ( “ the colony ” ) . DATE he was treated for tuberculosis . It was indicated that he would shortly be examined to determine whether he needed dental and ophthalmological treatment and orthopaedic footwear . In DATE the applicant was treated for his diabetes , diabetic angiopathy ( the generic term for a disease of the blood vessels ) and other diseases . The doctors recommended oral medication to lower blood glucose and a diet . The applicant received medication by PERSON , an oral blood - glucose - lowering drug . It does not transpire from the available medical record that any blood or urine tests were carried out DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant lodged complaints in relation to the allegedly inadequate treatment of his diabetes , unavailability of books on diabetes , insufficient nutrition and some other matters relating to medical care . On DATE ORG stated that it was not incumbent on this office or another public authority to supply books to individual detainees ; that all relevant counselling on diabetes could be obtained from the detainee ’s doctor , and that the applicant had been examined by a therapist on a number of occasions and received the necessary medication , including oral medication by PERSON . Another complaint was examined on DATE by ORG . It rejected the applicant ’s complaints , indicating that no special or high - vitamin diet was required for prisoners suffering from diabetes ; that they were to be fed according to the standard set by ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) ; that the applicant was given appropriate medication ; and that in DATE he would be able to have a medical consultation concerning his requests for dental treatment , orthopaedic footwear and an eyesight check - up .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE blood and urine tests were carried out ; the applicant also had an X - ray , which showed no anomalies . From DATE to DATE he was admitted to prison hospital no . CARDINAL to receive dental treatment . The applicant was diagnosed with a partial maxillary and full mandibular adentia ( loss of teeth ) connected to his then sub - compensated diabetes status . The applicant also had various blood and urine tests ( glucose , bilirubin , lipoproteid , cholesterol , alanine and aspartate aminotransferase ) . He was examined by specialist doctors ( a surgeon , a neuropathologist and an ophthalmologist ) who recommended regular medical check - ups . The ophthalmologist diagnosed slight myopia in both eyes and angiopathy . The applicant also had chronic pancreatitis but was in a stable condition . The applicant was given a dental prosthesis and instructions on how to use it . The final recommendations in the discharge certificate included provision of enzymes when needed , a low carbohydrate diet , DATE blood and urine tests , as well as exclusion of medication by PERSON .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant complained about chest pain and was given medication . In DATE he had a check - up by a physician , an ophthalmologist , a dentist and a surgeon . No specific prescriptions were made . The dentist indicated that the applicant ’s oral cavity “ had been sanitised ” . On an unspecified date the applicant handed over his allegedly defective dental prosthesis to his lawyer , apparently , to have this prosthesis adjusted . Subsequently he was examined by a radiologist and a tuberculosis specialist . On a number of occasions he was given medication for his headaches , hypertension and insomnia . The applicant had several check - ups and X - rays in DATE , DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . As follows from the applicant ’s medical record compiled in colony no . CARDINAL , various blood tests were carried out twice in DATE ( DATE and DATE ) ; CARDINAL times in DATE ( DATE , DATE , CARDINAL and DATE , DATE ) ; CARDINAL times in DATE ( DATE , CARDINAL and DATE , DATE and DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE ) ; CARDINAL times in DATE ( DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE ) and at least once in DATE ( DATE ) . Urine tests were carried out in DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE , and DATE .
CARDINAL . The applicant wrote to ORG , requesting his re - admission to prison hospital no . CARDINAL . This letter was forwarded to ORG . On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s request as follows :

“ The complaint has been examined by the medical unit of ORG . Since DATE [ the applicant ’s ] state of health has been monitored in the colony ... In DATE he was examined and received treatment inter alia from a dentist in prison hospital no . CARDINAL . He was discharged from this hospital in a satisfactory condition and was given recommendations to be followed within the regime of an out - patient observation . At present , his state of health is satisfactory ; the most recent laboratory tests were carried out in DATE . For the time being , a consultation with a dentist was not possible because [ the applicant ] did not have his dental prosthesis ( which he had handed over to his lawyer ) .
In - patient treatment in the prison hospital is not necessary . ”

CARDINAL . The applicant was examined again in DATE by a medical panel composed of the governor of the prison hospital and the head officers of the gastroenteritis and neurology units in this hospital . The applicant ’s condition was classified as satisfactory . The medical panel confirmed the diabetes ( Type CARDINAL ) diagnosis and symptoms of encephalopathy . The panel concluded that the applicant did not require in - patient treatment in the prison hospital and made the following recommendations :

“ to carry out a glycemic profiling ( TIME before eating and at TIME ) ; to follow a low fat and carbohydrate diet ( which has been followed by the patient on his own) ... and to continue intake of ORG ( TIME ) , and treatment by vasoactive and nootropic substances . ”

CARDINAL . The management of GPE colony no . CARDINAL in GPE affirmed in a certificate dated DATE , produced by the Government , that they could not provide the applicant with orthopaedic footwear because it could only be manufactured in another town and there was a long waiting list . Apparently , the applicant had been detained in this colony in DATE . The management of GPE medical facility no . CARDINAL stated in a certificate dated DATE , produced by the Government , that the applicant needed orthopaedic footwear ; however , the relevant regulations on supplies to convicted detainees did not require that it be provided by the ORG . The applicant had been detained in this medical facility in DATE .

CARDINAL . A certificate dated CARDINAL DATE and issued by NORP colony no . CARDINAL ( in GPE ) states that during the entire period of his detention in that detention facility the applicant was provided with adequate medication , including glucose - related medicines and CARDINAL meals per day . The management of the colony also stated in a certificate dated DATE , produced by the Government , as follows :
“ [ The applicant ] was not given a prescription for any special diet and receives a ration in compliance with the standards adopted for convicted detainees . ”
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE ORG issued a report in relation to the applicant ’s grievances previously raised before various national authorities and ORG . The report reads as follows :

“ In DATE the applicant was transferred to colony no . CARDINAL , where on numerous occasions he underwent out - patient examinations and treatment in relation to various diseases . He was also admitted to prison hospital no . CARDINAL , from which he was discharged in a satisfactory condition , provided that recovery had been obtained for acute illnesses and that amelioration had been observed for chronic diseases ...

The medical unit of the colony has the requisite licences for providing health care ( medication , out - patient treatment , therapy and assessment of disability ) . The colony has the requisite medical staff ( head of the unit , CARDINAL therapists and CARDINAL medical assistants ) with the necessary qualifications ...

For providing consultations on diagnoses and hospitalisation the above staff is assisted by external specialists from hospital no . CARDINAL or municipal or ORG medical institutions ... Certain types of health care ( dental treatment , X - ray imaging , laboratory testing ) are carried out in the medical unit of prison no . CARDINAL .

In DATE [ the applicant ] received dental treatment and prosthesis in prison hospital no . CARDINAL and was discharged from it in a satisfactory condition . The final recommendations included a low carbohydrate diet . In DATE he handed over the prosthesis to advocate PERSON , as can be seen from [ the applicant ’s ] written statement . After DATE he did not request a replacement of prosthesis from the medical unit of prison no . CARDINAL .

Food is supplied [ to the applicant ] in the colony in compliance with the standards set in Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE by ORG ... Since DATE he has been receiving CARDINAL meals per day in order to impede undesired changes in the blood glucose levels . The recommendations for a low carbohydrate diet and low glucose have been followed [ by the applicant ] under monitoring by the medical personnel in the colony .

[ The applicant ] has no disability status . No recommendation for orthopaedic footwear was issued . The regime for detainees on life sentences does not require any substantial movement , except for outdoor exercise ...

[ The applicant ] was and continues to be provided with medical care in compliance with Decree no . ORG issued by ORG and ORG . Such medical care is provided within the framework of the ORG programme concerning provision of free medical assistance to NORP nationals .
During his detention [ the applicant ] was given all requisite medical monitoring and treatment ... ”

CARDINAL . NORP The management of NORP colony no . CARDINAL in GPE affirmed in a document dated DATE and produced by the Government that they had no document which indicated that the applicant had asked them for special footwear or that it had been recommended ( see also paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The Government also submitted written statement made in DATE by a medical assistant in colony no . CARDINAL , who affirmed that the applicant could walk independently without any assistance and , in the absence of disability status , did not need special footwear .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , he was not provided with orthopaedic footwear , which was necessary on account of the injuries to his feet . In the absence of such footwear , he suffered pain in his feet and could hardly keep his balance , for instance during long routine line - ups organised by the prison staff or when cleaning cells ; his standard footwear did not fit him properly and wore out quickly . For DATE , the applicant was kept in a cell on the ground floor of the detention facility and had difficulty , in the absence of special footwear , to walk up and down the stairs to / from the first and second floors where the medical unit and the offices of the prison staff were located .

CARDINAL . The applicant brought civil proceedings before LOC of GPE ( “ the ORG ” ) against ORG of the ORG , ORG , ORG of GPE and CARDINAL detention facilities . The applicant alleged , inter alia , that he had not been provided with the requisite medical assistance in DATE ; as a result of medical negligence , parts of his feet had had to be amputated ; and he had not been given a special diet adapted to his diabetes in DATE . His claim was dismissed on procedural grounds on several occasions .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant resubmitted his above claims to ORG . The court opened a file and sought the applicant ’s observations on the need for an expert report to be commissioned . In DATE and DATE the applicant wrote to ORG giving his consent for an expert report to be commissioned and suggested that some questions be put to the expert ( see also paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant also wrote to ORG asking that he be brought to court hearings in his civil case . The court dispatched summons to the applicant in prison . However , it issued no order for his transfer for any hearings . On CARDINAL and DATE ORG held hearings and heard the prosecutor , the defendants and witnesses . The applicant was neither present nor represented at these hearings .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the presiding judge asked to see the applicant ’s medical record from prison hospital PERCENT CARDINAL in NORP .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE a Mr Sh . applied to ORG on behalf of the applicant , asking for the applicant ’s medical file , in particular in relation to DATE . He was informed that the applicant ’s medical record had been destroyed because the building in which the hospital had filed it had been flooded in DATE .

CARDINAL . An expert report was commissioned and carried out on the basis of the available material . The expert concluded that the surgical operation in DATE had been justified ; the applicant ’s diabetes was hereditary and its treatment had been appropriate , including PERSON ; and that an adequate diet had been given to the applicant . It was noted in this connection that type CARDINAL diabetes required diet no.CARDINAL , which consisted in CARDINAL or QUANTITY servings of food per day excluding or replacing sugar and reducing carbohydrates . A copy of the expert report was sent to the applicant in DATE . According to the applicant , he never saw the documents which served as a basis for the expert report .

CARDINAL . Hearings in DATE and DATE were adjourned in the absence of any proof that the applicant had been properly notified . On DATE the court received a letter from the applicant in which he commented on the expert report and also sought his own participation in the hearing and access to the medical documents submitted by the defendants .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a hearing at which the applicant was neither present nor represented . By a judgment of DATE , ORG rejected his claims . The applicant appealed . The defendants submitted their observations in reply . On DATE the applicant was provided with a copy of the verbatim record of the trial . In DATE he was served with a copy of the defendants’ observations .
CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant was informed that an appeal hearing was listed for DATE and that “ his absence would not halt the proceedings ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE heard the representative of ORG . The applicant was neither present nor represented at the appeal hearing . At the closure of this hearing ORG upheld the first - instance judgment . In DATE the applicant received a copy of the appeal decision .

CARDINAL . NORP law gives detailed guidelines for the provision of medical assistance to detained individuals . These guidelines , found in joint Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of ORG and ORG , on ORG or Detained ( “ the Regulation ” ) , enacted on DATE , are applicable to all detainees without exception . In particular , section III of the Regulation sets out the procedure for initial steps to be taken by medical personnel of a detention facility on admission of a detainee . On arrival at a temporary detention facility all detainees must be subjected to preliminary medical examination before they are placed in cells shared by other inmates . The examination is performed with the aim of identifying individuals suffering from contagious diseases or in need of urgent medical assistance . DATE after the detainee ’s arrival at the detention facility , he should receive a medical examination , including fluorography . During the in - depth examination a prison doctor should record the detainee ’s complaints , study his medical and personal history , record injuries if present , and recent tattoos , and schedule additional medical procedures if necessary . A prison doctor should also authorise laboratory analyses to identify sexually transmitted diseases , HIV , tuberculosis and other illnesses .

CARDINAL . Subsequent medical examinations of detainees are performed at least twice a DATE or at GPE request . If a detainee ’s state of health has deteriorated , medical examinations and assistance should be provided by medical personnel of the detention facility . In such cases a medical examination should include a general medical check - up and additional methods of testing , if necessary , with the participation of particular medical specialists . The results of the examinations should be recorded in the detainee ’s medical history . The detainee should be fully informed of the results of the medical examinations .

CARDINAL . Section III of the ORG also sets the procedure for cases of refusals by detainees to undergo medical examination or treatment . In each case of refusal , a corresponding entry should be made in the detainees’ medical record . A prison doctor should fully explain to the detainee the consequences of his refusal to undergo the medical procedure .

CARDINAL . Detainees take prescribed medicines in the presence of a doctor . In a limited number of cases the head of the medical department of the detention facility may authorise his medical personnel to hand over a DATE dose of medicines to the detainee for unobserved intake .

CARDINAL . Until DATE food supplies for detainees were regulated by Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE of ORG . Since DATE they have been regulated by Decree no . CARDINAL . Neither decree has provided for any specific diet for detainees suffering from diabetes .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a standard protocol for out - patient treatment of persons suffering from non - insulin - dependent diabetes . The protocol recommends , inter alia , a DATE provision of CARDINAL glucose ( laboratory ) tests and/or for CARDINAL glucose meter tests .

CARDINAL . The Code of Civil Procedure of GPE ( “ the ORG ” ) provides that individuals may appear before a court in person or act through a representative ( LAW ) . A court may appoint a lawyer to represent a defendant whose place of residence is not known ( LAW . LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL-FZ of DATE ) provides that free legal assistance may be provided to indigent plaintiffs in court proceedings in civil disputes concerning alimony or pension payments or claims for compensation for employment - related health damage ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . In DATE ORG launched a test project in a number of regions concerning provision of free legal assistance in civil law matters ( Decree no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ) .

CARDINAL . Articles DATE and CARDINAL of the ORG provide that parties may seek a court ’s assistance in obtaining evidence . The relevant party should indicate the circumstances impeding access to such evidence and its relevance to the case , as well as the location from where such evidence should be collected . An unjustified failure to comply with the court order could lead to the person or official in possession of the relevant evidence being fined .

CARDINAL . In a given civil case a civil court could ask a court in another location to carry out specific actions in relation to the evidence situated in that location ( LAW ORG ) . This request is mandatory and has to be carried out within DATE from its receipt .

CARDINAL . Under Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG , a court may hold a session outside the court - house if , for instance , it is necessary to examine evidence which can not be brought to the court - house .

CARDINAL . As follows from Ruling no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE by ORG of GPE , complaints brought by detainees in relation to the inappropriate conditions of detention ( for instance , a lack of adequate medical assistance ) should be examined by a court under the procedure prescribed by LAW of the ORG . The latter provides that a person may bring court proceedings if an action or omission by a public authority or official violated this person ’s rights or freedoms , impeded their exercise or unlawfully imposed an obligation or liability ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG ) . Such court action should be lodged within DATE when the person learnt about the violation of his or her rights or freedoms ( LAW ) . If a court considers that the complaint is justified , the court orders the respondent authority or official to remedy the violation ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The Penitentiary Code provides that convicted persons may be transferred from a correctional colony to an investigative unit if their participation is required as witnesses , victims or suspects in connection with certain investigative measures ( Article CARDINAL ) . A convicted person may consult his or her lawyer ( ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On several occasions ORG examined complaints by convicted persons whose requests for leave to appear in civil proceedings had been refused by courts . It has consistently declared the complaints inadmissible , finding that the contested provisions of LAW and LAW did not , as such , restrict the convicted person ’s access to court . It has emphasised , nonetheless , that the convicted person should be able to make submissions to the civil court , either through a representative or in any other way provided by law . If necessary , the hearing may be held at the location where the convicted person is serving the sentence , or the court in which the case is being heard may instruct the court having territorial jurisdiction over the correctional colony to obtain the applicant ’s submissions or take any other procedural action ( decisions no . CARDINAL-O of DATE , no . CARDINAL of DATE and no . CARDINAL of DATE ) .
CARDINAL . The Code of Civil Procedure , as interpreted by ORG in its ruling no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE , allows for a reopening of the domestic civil proceedings on the basis of a ORG judgment .
